Requirements & Use Cases

Requirements

This section covers the requirements and use cases of the website as well as requirements of the user interface. We use the FURPS framework for splitting up and categorising our requirements into Functional requirements, and Non-Functional requirements including Usability, Reliability, Performance and Supportability.

Functional Requirements:

What does the website need to do? What are its features and capabilities

ID Requirement MoSCoW
F1 The website shall allow a non-technical administrative user to edit and manage the website's pages through the use of WordPress. Must Have
F2 The website shall allow a non-technical administrative user to add, edit and remove events on the events page. Must Have
F3 The website shall allow a non-technical administrative user to write, edit, and remove blog posts on the news page. Must Have
F4 The website shall allow a non-technical administrative user to upload files available for download on the Referral Forms website. Must Have
F5 The website shall store a number of services in a database. A non-technical administrative user must be able to add, edit or remove entries in a user-friendly way through the use of a Graphical User Interface (GUI). Must Have
F6 The website shall be able to collect the details of a user submitted form and store them in a database and return relevant services to the user from the database. Must Have
F7 The website shall be able to scroll to a certain part of the page when a user selects a link. Must Have
F8 The website shall be able to allow users to search for contact details of a certain hospital or the contact details for hospitals that can deal with a certain cancer pathway. Should Have
F9 The website shall allow a non-technical administrative user to edit the content on the front page. Should Have
F10 The website shall allow users to sign up to a emailing list hosted by MailChimp. Should Have

Usability Requirements:

The user experience, Aesthetics, Consistency, Documentation, Legal, Responsiveness

ID Requirement MoSCoW
U1 The website shall be easy to navigate on any device. Must Have
U2 The website shall use the existing style guidelines provided London Cancer. Must Have
U3 The website shall keep a consistent style. Should Have
U4 The website shall be optimised and easy to use on desktop, tablet and mobile devices. Must Have
U5 The website shall have documentation for administrative users to how the website is structured and how to edit its content via WordPress. Must Have
U6 The website shall let a user change its text size on content pages. Should Have
U7 The website shall be accessible to those who are visually impaired. Should Have
U8 The website shall have multiple languages available for content. Should Have
U9 The website should notify users of the use of any cookies and for there consent. Should Have

Reliability Requirements:

Availability, Robustness, Security and Recoverability

ID Requirement MoSCoW
R1 The website should be online and available at all times except when being maintained or updated. Must Have
R2 The website should be robust and not crash for any reason. Must Have
R3 The website should be secure and safe. Must Have
R4 The website should use HTTPS to encrypt user traffic. Should Have
R5 The website should be recoverable and should be automatically backed up every week to two different offsite locations. Should Have

Performance Requirements:

Speed, Resource Consumption, Scalability

ID Requirement MoSCoW
P1 The website should have fast loading times across all devices. Should Have
P2 The website shall aim to score highly on Google's Pagespeed Insights. Should Have
P3 The website should consume server resources efficiently. Should Have
P4 The website should be easy to scale in in the case of heavy website usage. Should Have

Supportability Requirements:

Installability , Testability, Extensibility and Maintainability

ID Requirement MoSCoW
S1 The website shall be trivial to get up and running on a server. Should Have
S2 The website shall pass all code tests, some automated, some manual. Should Have
S3 The website shall pass all browser tests of browsers dating back to Internet Explorer 8. Must Have
S4 The website shall be easy to modify and extend. Should Have
S5 The website shall have a minimum amount of work for its maintenance. Should Have
S6 The website shall have documentation covering all of the above aspects. Must Have

Use Cases

Use Case: EditingAPage
ID: UC1
Relevant Requirement ID: F1
Brief Description: The website Administrator edits a page of content.
Primary Actors: Administrator
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: Administrator is logged into WordPress.
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the Administrator accesses the Pages section of the WordPress dashboard.
  2. WordPress displays a list of the website's pages.
  3. The Administrator selects the content page that they would like to edit by selecting 'Edit'.
  4. The Administrator makes changes to the content using the WordPress page editor.
  5. The Administrator selects 'Update Page' to save their changes.
Post Conditions: WordPress saves the changes to the database and updates the pages content to be displayed on the website.
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: AddingAnEvent
ID: UC2
Relevant Requirement ID: F2
Brief Description: Add an Event
Primary Actors: Administrator
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: The Administrator is logged into WordPress.
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the Administrator accesses the Events page
  2. The Administrator then selects the 'Add Event'.
  3. WordPress displays a New Event page where the title, date, time, location and description can be filled in.
  4. The Administrator fills in these fields and selects 'Save Event'.
Post Conditions: WordPress saves the event to the database and displays the event on the Events Page.
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: AddingABlogPost
ID: UC3
Relevant Requirement ID: F3
Brief Description: The Administrator adds a blog post to the News page.
Primary Actors: Administrator
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: The Administrator is logged into WordPress.
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the Administrator accesses the Posts page.
  2. The Administrator then selects 'Add Post'.
  3. The Administrator then fills in the title of the post and the content the post contains.
  4. The Administrator then selects 'Save Post'.
Post Conditions: WordPress saves the post to the database and updates the News page with the latest post.
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: UploadGPReferralForm
ID: UC4
Relevant Requirement ID: F4
Brief Description: Administrator wants to upload a GP Referral Form to the GP Referral Forms Page.
Primary Actors: Administrator
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: The Administrator is logged into WordPress.
Main Flow:
  • The use case starts when the Administrator accesses the Pages section.
  • The Administrator selects the GP Referral Forms page by selecting 'Edit'.
  • The Administrator navigates through the content editor to select an area of the page which they'd like to add a file to download.
  • The Administrator then selects Add Media and selects Select Files, choosing the GP Referral Form to upload
  • The Administrator then selects 'Insert into page'
  • The Administrator selects 'Update'
Post Conditions: WordPress updates saves the updated page to the database ready to be shown for a user to download the latest GP Referral Form.
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: AddServiceToDirectoryOfServices
ID: UC5
Relevant Requirement ID: F5
Brief Description: Add a service to the directory of services.
Primary Actors: Administrator
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: The Administrator is logged into WordPress.
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the Administrator selects the Directory of Services Plugin and selects Add a Service.
  2. The Administrator selects the borough of the service, the services type, and its subtype.
  3. The Administrator additionally enters the Name, Services Offered, Address, Telephone numbers, Email and Website into text fields
  4. The Administrator selects 'Save Service'
Post Conditions: A service is added to the database and can be viewed via the Directory of Services
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: StoreUserDetailsAndDisplayRelevantServices
ID: UC6
Relevant Requirement ID: F6
Brief Description: When a user enters some details about services they require on the website it returns with relevant services while also saving these details sercurely to a log.
Primary Actors: User
Secondary Actors: WordPress
Preconditions: The User is on the Directory of Services page.
Main Flow:
  1. The User selects from a series of dropdowns the borough, service type and sub-type that they require as well as details about whether they are a Patient, General Practitioner or Cancer Professional and selects 'Search'.
  2. WordPress saves this information securely in a log, and pulls services that are relevant from the database and displays them.
Post Conditions: The User can now view and scroll through a series of information about services that fit their needs
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: PageScrollingToSection
ID: UC7
Relevant Requirement ID: F7
Brief Description: When User selects a link in the sidebar it will scroll to a certain part of the page and display the relevant content.
Primary Actors: User
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: User is on a page of the website with multiple sections of content
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the User selects a part of content they would like to view in the sidebar
  2. WordPress then automatically scrolls down the page to that section of content.
Post Conditions: User can now view certain section of page without having to scroll and find it manually
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: HospitalContactDetails
ID: UC8
Relevant Requirement ID: F8
Brief Description: User interacts with map or selects options to find a hospital that deals with their cancer.
Primary Actors: Cancer Patient
Secondary Actors: WordPress
Preconditions: The Cancer Patient is on the website.
Main Flow:
  1. Cancer Patient selects a hospital or a cancer pathway from dropdown list and selects 'Search'
  2. WordPress then finds relevant hospitals from the database and displays them on the page.
Post Conditions: The user can now use this information to contact or travel to a hospital.
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: EditHomePage
ID: UC9
Relevant Requirement ID: F9
Brief Description: The Homepage is full of 'Widgets' that the Administrator is able to edit.
Primary Actors: Administrator
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions: The Administrator is logged into WordPress
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the Administrator selects the Widgets Page
  3. The Administrator then selects the content of the specific Widget they would like to edit
  4. The Administrator then selects 'Save'.
Post Conditions: WordPress saves the Widget to the database and updates the Widget on the homepage.
Alternative Flows:
Use Case: EmailListSignup
ID: UC10
Relevant Requirement ID: F10
Brief Description: The user is able to sign up to an emailing list to subscribe for London Cancer updates.
Primary Actors: User
Secondary Actors:
Preconditions:
Main Flow:
  1. The use case starts when the User is on a content page.
  3. The User sees a widget encouraging the user to signup to the signup page.
  4. The User enters their email address and selects 'Subscribe'.
Post Conditions: The email is securely saved in a Mailchimp mailing list database.
Alternative Flows:
